On Mon, 08 Nov 2004 16:56:18 +0000, Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
>          I read your paper.
> 
>          It's good.  The only comment I had is the same one I had before,
> that you do not define the "nearest neighbour" algorithm used in zooming
> the images and the picture you show does not look like what I think of as
> nearest neighbour.  But I doubt that many in your audience will pick up on
> that and I don't know whether it matters anyway...

Thanks for the feedback, Ian.

Yes, we could have spent a bit more space discussing interpolation
algorithms, but thought it might be a distraction.  We might possibly
be asked to add something in by reviewers, if it makes it that far.

>          In what sense is the image processing the bottleneck?  Is is
> because you have to zoom, translate and rotate the viewed portion of the
> image in every evaluation frame?

Yes, basically.  Each individual gets about 100 steps to move across
the canvass and view portions of the image.  On a given step, the
image can be moved up/down, left/right, zoomed in/out, and rotated, so
there's an affine transform for every step, and this is
computationally expensive.

>  Writing your own (simple) image manipulation in
> C will cut the run-time hugely.  If you are already doing that then your
> problem is more severe...

No, right now we're using Java's image processing package.  We're
looking at using a package called ImageMagick, and exploiting native
methods to speed up the processing.

But we also hope to use Jim's SEMIANN neural net framework to gain
some speed there.

Derek
